This is a mashup of 2 different recipes:
[pad kee mao](https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1023044-pad-kee-mao-drunken-noodles) and 
[ginger pork noodles](https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1016023-spicy-ginger-pork-noodles-with-bok-choy).

![Johnny Miller for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Rebecca Jurkevich.](https://static01.nyt.com/images/2022/03/23/dining/17padthairex3/merlin_203116365_994a1217-d3d5-40d9-b26b-a6718a450b67-threeByTwoMediumAt2X.jpg?width=1280&quality=75&auto=webp)

---

- 12 oz noodles, cooked to pkg directions (spaghetti, wide Thai noodles, rice noodles, etc.)
- 2 Tbs oyster sauce
- 3 Tbs soy sauce
- 1 Tbs fish sauce
- 2 Tbs Chianking black vinegar or balsamic vinegar
- 3 Thai chiles or 1 jalape√±o
- 1 oz slivered ginger
- 3 garlic cloves, sliced
- 3 Tbs vegetable oil
- 8 oz ground pork
- 12 oz baby bok choy or gai lan or spinach (not baby), cut into bite size pieces.
- 1 cup Thai basil or a mix of sliced scallions and cilantro

---

1. Make the noodles.
1. Prepare the sauce. Mix together the oyster sauce, soy sauce, fish sauce,
and vinegar.
1. Heat a large pan or wok to medium and add the vegetable oil. Cook pork until
lightly browned.
1. Meanwhile, mix the noodles with the sauce in a large bowl.
1. Add the greens (stems first if they are sturdy) and cook until wilted.
1. Add the noodles and reheat. Be careful not to break them too much. Add the 
basil, remove from heat, dump back into the bowl, mix a bit more, and serve.
